content:
I thought I would solicit some input from fresh eyes. Not sure if I'll get any, but it's worth a try.

https://twitter.com/StPaulTim/status/1224806640953765890

The @backdropcms community is looking for feedback on which chat tool would be easier to join AND use for our community. We want to avoid the temptation to cater to the power users in our group and remain as accessible AND usable to the larger community. (1 of 2)

- Tim Erickson (@StPaulTim)

I believe that some people are concerned that moving from Gitter to Zulip will serve the needs of power users in our community and limit or discourage new people from joining. I disagree with that, but would love to get input from someone that is not already active in our chat community.

I am just now realizing how I can scroll back through all the topics in a channel and not just see the most recent ones. In the past, I only looked at the most recent 8-10 or so.

Zulip_-_Backdrop_CMS.png
I think I never clicked on "more topics" AND scrolled before.
Maybe the chat tool's primary audience should be considered the "power users". This is different from the forum which should be especially geared towards being super easy to use. At least in my mind
By power user, I think we mean people who know what GitHub is for and are motivated to sign up. And also to participate in chat discussions geared towards looking at the plumbing
But even then I think Zulip is pretty easy to use

@Herb - I don't disagree. But, I am also sympathetic with the desire to use the tools that are mostly likely to appeal to the broadest audience. As you know, I favor Zulip and tend to believe that we'll get more, not less, participation in Zulip, but I understand this concern.

I think that we can learn from the long standing tension in the Drupal community over the use of IRC or Slack. Power users loved IRC, but it was not at all welcoming to new users.

I think Zulip does a good job of catering to novice users by dumping everyone into the "General" stream upon signing in -- which is like Gitter with the benefits of threaded topics. But it also allows "power users" to opt in to more complex streams that might deter novices at first glance (e.g. Code Review)
in - oops! Sorry about that. (Karma: -1)
oops!++ Shakes fist at dragonbot
oops! - Dragon Fire (Karma: 1)
Hello! @StPaulTim you succeeded in getting me in here. :)

Hi, Jack Aponte. Welcome to the Backdrop CMS community on Zulip. I'm your friendly neighborhood Dragonbot. Try '@Dragonbot help' for a list of things I can help you with. There are lots of friendly humans that hang around here, so please feel free to ask questions.
Well I will admit that Zulip seems weird as all get out
I feel so disoriented! Where do I just put random thoughts? What are all these streams and topics? Feels a bit like when I started using Diaspora and couldn't help comparing it to Facebook.
How are "All messages" sorted? Are topics sorted by most recently updated? (probably!) So many questions!
Mostly just typing all of this here to give it a try. :)
@Jack the messages are sorted by time, regardless of whether you are viewing a stream or not.
@oadaeh (Jason Flatt) Gotcha, I see that now. :)
Ooh, more sold on threading now that I see how it works in the #Contrib stream.

I definitely agree that Zulip is initially a bit disorientating and that many of us were briefly confused by how topics/threads work at first. I believe that one gets used to them pretty quickly. But, it's not obvious at first.

We want to avoid the temptation to cater to the power users

@StPaulTim Can you define 'power user'? Does this refer just to chatting, or to Backdrop in general (e.g. core contributes, etc.)?

I would argue that Zulip can make people 'power users' by making it easier to find, follow and participate in discussions. There's already been at least one comment where someone's admitted to not participating in Gitter much because they don't like it and find it frustrating. Maybe Zulip will create more 'power users' in our community...

The fact that both Gitter and Zulip allow people to sign up/in using their GitHub account does not mean that a GitHub account is required. People can still use their emails to sign up, so I don't see it as a "power" tool - just another chat system with GitHub integration.

I have not used Zulip in a couple of weeks now. That was intentional - I wanted to see what it feels like to come back after some time (simulating returning from leave/holidays) ...I must say that I find it less frustrating with the thread/topic feature. Now I can slowly pick and choose topics that I'm interested in the most, and slowly catch up ...with Gitter, there'd be soooo much scrolling up and down, in order to read and reply to all.
And it's easy to lose your place while going through the unread messages, due to them being marked read when just scrolling to where you left off. (In Gitter)
@klonos Was wondering why I hadn't seen you around here much (at all) :grinning_face_with_smiling_eyes:
@klonos that's what I found frustrating with Gitter too. Sometimes even leaving for a day meant I lost track of all the cross-conversations

I see 302 unread messages in #General ...but that doesn't discourage me :slight_smile: ...I can take one thread/topic at a time and work my way through them, till I read everything that I'm interested in following ...which in my case is EVERYTHING :sweat_smile: ...now I can take my time, and do that at a pace that does not make this task seem like a chore ...so :+1:

I'm adding my two cents here... As someone who only enters the chat infrequently, I find Zulip much easier. In Gitter I'm not able to follow previous discussions, in Zulip with its streams and threads it's a breeze.

Whether or not Jitsi gets used for Weekly Meetings, it is a benefit to have such an easy way to start a voice/video conversation. I just had a private message with someone and we were able to set up a Jitsi call to talk live for 5-10 minutes right within the private message.
